Award.AwardTitle: Disorder and Dynamics in Silicate and Aluminosilicate Liquids, Glasses and Crystals Relevant to Geochemical Processes: Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Studies
Award.AbstractNarration:
Silicate and aluminosilicate materials make up most of the minerals, rocks, and magmas that are at the center of geological processes. Particularly for those processes that take place at the high pressures and temperatures of the Earth's interior (and thus that are hard to observe directly), our ability to interpret what has happened in past Earth history from the geological record, and thus to predict what might take place in the future (for example, when and how volcanoes erupt), depends on a fundamental understanding of how the atomic-scale structure controls material behavior. This research program focuses on measuring this structure for synthetic, somewhat simplified analogs of solid and molten minerals and their glassy equivalents, to provide input for more accurate modeling of critical properties such as density, viscosity, heat capacity, and energy. In particular, the structures of disordered materials, which cannot be readily addressed by other, more conventional methods, are studied using Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy.

NMR is uniquely capable for quantifying the short- to intermediate-range structures of crystalline minerals that contain certain common types of structural disorder, and of molten materials and the glasses produced by rapid cooling of melts. This method will be the primary research tool in this program. Among the structural questions that will be addressed include the critical, but still poorly known, effects of temperature and pressure on the arrangements of atoms around, and distances between, such ions as silicon, aluminum, oxygen, sodium, calcium and magnesium, which are among the predominant constituents of natural minerals and magmas. The increase of disorder among these ions, which is the primary effect of the very high temperatures of volcanic processes, and their increasingly dense packing at the enormous pressures of the Earth's interior, will be measured. The results will be analyzed in terms of structural models for their bulk physical properties, which in term are needed to predict geological processes. New methods for structural studies, using NMR in materials containing magnetic ions such as iron and rare earth elements, will be developed. These studies will be important not only for geological materials, but also for ceramic and glass materials that are critical to a number of advanced technologies, including fuel cells, optical data fibers and substrates for computer screens and solar cells. Results from this project should lead to significant improvements in our fundamental understanding of many types of silicate materials, as well as to the development of new methods for their analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most of the Earth and other terrestrial planets is made up of silicate and oxide rocks and minerals, many of which have formed from hot, molten liquids (magmas). Crystalline, molten, and glassy silicate and oxide materials are thus at the center of most of the processes that have formed the planet and continue to affect human activities through earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, formation of deposits of natural resources, and the landscapes in which we all live. Our fundamental understanding of such materials, and our abilities to predict and model their properties and behaviors at the high temperatures and pressures of the Earth’s interior, require detailed knowledge of their atomic-scale structures. The general goal of this project has been to quantify the structures of silicate and oxide minerals and glasses (quenched melts) of importance to major geological processes in the Earth. We have focused on materials in which the atomic arrangements are highly disordered, and thus often difficult to measure with common structural tools such as X-ray diffraction. Our primary experimental tool is Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR), which provides detailed and quantitative information about the short-range (atomic and molecular-scale) structure around atoms of many of the chemical elements that are most abundant in the Earth, including silicon (Si), aluminum (Al), oxygen (O), sodium (Na), and phosphorus (P).

The research supported by this grant has lead to important new discoveries about the structures of silicate glasses that inform us about properties of high temperature melts and magmas in nature. For example, we showed that conventional models of chemical composition on melt structure, which describe how cations (positively charged ions) and anions (negatively charged ions) join to form stiff, viscous networks, are much too simple in detail and that previously unseen structural groups can be important and may have major effects on melt properties.  Examples include the presence of Al cations with five and six O neighbors instead of four, and of loosely bonded “non-bridging” oxygen ions in compositions where these were thought to be absent.  We have also focused on the effects of pressure on melt structure, as magmas in the modern Earth are usually formed at depths of up to about 100 km, where pressures reach about 30,000 times that of the planet’s surface. Using a new experimental approach, we have shown that many previous experiments on pressure effects on structures give only minimum estimates of the actual changes. Our new data show that structure-based models of melt properties, even for this relatively “modest” pressures, will need to be significantly revised.

A number of other projects supported by this grant have provided new and unique structural information on minor element substitutions into oxide minerals important in the deep Earth. These include geochemically interesting but relatively rare minerals such high pressure titanium dioxide (rutile), as well as the minerals that are most abundant in the Earth’s upper and lower mantle, olivine and magnesium silicate perovskite, the latter recently named “bridgemanite”. We have collaborated as well on measuring aspects of the structures of highly disordered oxide materials of major interest in near-surface and environmental geochemical processes, such as amorphous silica (silicon dioxide) and nanocrystalline ferrihydrite (iron hydroxide).

We also made a major effort in developing solid-state NMR methods for determining the distributions of elements in oxide crystal structures, when magnetic ions (having unpaired electron spins) are present.
